item.title: The Final Showdown (Andrew Adams and Southborne)
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Cool. Thanks for that.

Who â€˜ownsâ€™ the track at the end? All contributors equally?
What would happen if the track took off and started generating income?

Or is it all very organic and informal and not something that was discussed or considered?

I know theyâ€™re boring, pragmatic questions, but Iâ€™m interested in your thoughts. Thanks.

 
(I broached a â€˜producerâ€™/co-production question a while back, but people misunderstood what I was talking about and it turned into a mess.)

item.title: The Final Showdown (Andrew Adams and Southborne)
item.dc:creator: Andrew_Adams
item.description:
Hey there! Well every collab process isnâ€™t the same, but for this one I started out with the build and then thought Iâ€™d have Southborne help me with the drop (cause I knew heâ€™s super good with them). Then I added some stuff, and he added some stuff, and we were done! Took a few weeks.

I think collabs work the best when you both focus on your strengths. For example if you want somebody to add a cool piano part in your song then ask someone whoâ€™s good at piano, or if you have a good build but donâ€™t quite know how to make the drop sound right, ask somebody whoâ€™s good at drops.

And thanks for the reminderâ€”youâ€™re right, I should use those tags more. To be honest Iâ€™ve only been on Auxy since the spring and Iâ€™m still trying to learn all the genres and stuff.

Read full topic

item.title: The Final Showdown (Andrew Adams and Southborne)
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Collabs happen fairly regularly here, but no-one really seems to talk about the process. I think that would be really interesting to hear about.

 
How long did it take from start to finish?

Did it start with a blank slate, or did one of you have the idea that you then developed together?
Or was there already a hook/theme or the core of a track, which was then developed by the other party?

Was it like remix tennis â€“ with versions bouncing back and forth? How many rounds of changes were there?

 
(Btw, you should always make sure to tag it with a music genre. Without any music genre tags, itâ€™s unlikely be included in SCâ€™s automated share/promotion algorithms (â€˜Related Tracksâ€™, â€˜The Uploadâ€™, â€˜Stationsâ€™). Using only #auxy might help promote it to others who use the #auxy tag, but ideally you want it reaching out as far as it can go.)

Read full topic
